job_title: Patient Access Associate in Everett, MA

job_title: Registered Nurse Behavioral Health in Everett, MA
pros: Diverse patient group who desperately need access to quality healthcare.
cons: Toxic environment, out of touch leadership- organization does not value nursing- especially in Somerville. Child and Adolescent service a chaotic and A dangerous mess. More than half of hospital beds are behavioral health and no one in upper nursing leadership has any inpatient psychiatric experience. Multiple staff out with serious injuries. Nurses viewed as an unfortunate overhead- are not members of the team and are not part of any decision making. Have never worked with Doctors and other disciplines that treated nurses this poorly. Talented nurse managers driven out or forced out. There is no culture of safety- any one who brings up concerns will pay the price. This is not a culture of safety or a high reliability organization. This a culture of shame and blame. Nurses bear the brunt of it- even as they struggle to retain nurses. Physicians go unchecked. The list of safety events is atrocious and unacceptable- and the most disenfranchised populations are the victims of this chaotic, short-sighted organization. Leadership adept at sweeping things under the rug- gaslighting and manipulation seem to be go to strategies. Work place violence not addressed.

pros: Supportive Friendly Stable Diverse Flexible
cons: Over load of work New project everyday Manager has favorite Nothing like they say women empowerment Often no smile

job_title: Quality Improvement Analyst in Cambridge, MA
pros: Salary, benefits and team effort
cons: Technology is a bit lagged

job_title: Staff RN, Psychiatry in Somerville, MA
pros: Coworkers, pay, benefits. Employee Assistance Program (KGA) is fantastic.
cons: * Management is toxic. Top down approach that uses favoritism, splitting, intimidation, retaliation, and humiliation to try to control the staff and the patients. Employees are afraid to speak up. Complaints to Risk Management, CEO and upper management fell on deaf ears. They would rather fire a good employee than face their flaws. * "Cover-up Culture... it is more important to protect the reputation of a system and those in power than it is to protect the basic human dignity of individuals or communities" - Brené Brown * Unsafe environment (adolescent psychiatry) - No limits or consequences creates a traumatic space for both staff and patients. Inconsistency of care. Nobody knows what is expected of them nor what they can expect from others. Mistrust, unreported assaults, property damage, frequent altercations, restraints, escapes. Patients run the show. It is chaotic. Toxic management reinforces negative behaviors by both patients and staff. * Inadequate and unprofessional training of staff. * Burnout due to unnecessary high levels of stress on the unit. * High turnover. Even though the pay is good, experienced workers don't stick around due to the toxic work environment.

pros: Great dedication to the mission and vision of providing psychological services to the underserved and undocumented.  Amazing colleagues with a great environment for personal enrichment, intellectual challenge, and interprofessional collaboration.
cons: Top heavy leadership and management is highly political and hierarchical.  Too many leaders with limited power to make actual meaningful changes in the day to day operations.  Those with the least power in the system that do the most work are often identified as the problem when conflicting management messages arise.  Management opens dialogue about opinions on changes for patient care, but does not actually take the feedback into account (token of a democratic, egalitarian system).  Individuals are asked to take on leadership roles and quality improvement projects with limited support (no time is bought out despite reiteration of the importance of these activities).  Management allots 8 hours per week for all clinical documentation, email and MyChart messaging, mandatory clinic meetings, leadership requests, and peer supervision.  Supervisors do not receive productivity credit for supervisees, and supervisors earn only one hour of credit per week per supervisee towards their three-hour Harvard rule, which is volunteered service time to maintain Harvard faculty status (does not account for curbside supervision or revisions/signing of notes).   Difficult to identify managers responsible for certain issues and reach out to leadership in effective ways (obscure hierarchical system that limits constructive feedback).

review_title: Would not recommend other pharmacy tech
job_title: Lead Pharmacy Technician CphT in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Health benefits and earned time as soon as you are hired. Parking garages in Cambridge with shuttles to work sites ($10/week).

They will work with your schedule if you have children or go to school. You can make your own schedule. Those without either will get the short end of the stick. 

If you apply, you most likely will be hired because the turn over rate is so high. Most techs don’t last more than 2 years. 

Certified/uncertified? CHA doesn’t really care, if you can wow them in the interview you’ll get paid more than certified techs who have been there more than 5 years.
cons:
Holidays are deducted from your earn time.  Management won’t let more than 3 techs off on a same day.  Good luck getting time off during the summer months. As other reviews have stated, management in the out patient pharmacy is very much a dictatorship. If you speak your mind, you will be forced to voluntarily quit by making your life miserable. They have never fired anyone because their tactics have always worked. 

If you are favored by upper management, you will be promoted, regardless of the work ethics or if the qualifications are met. Management does not check your resume for accuracy.  People have said they have x years of experience, when in reality they don’t even know the in and outs of the pharmacy.

pros: Autonomy, great learning experience, 1st assist experience
cons: Communication is lacking amongst various groups

pros: None. I don't recommend them to anyone.
cons: They consider their employees as a number. When push comes to shove it is always about them. Heartless management. Competition and jealousy are very prevalent here.

review_title: Great educational and staff meetings. Terrific patients. Not great morale of staff at that time.
pros: Some of the kindest, most knowledgeable, best-in-the-field clinicians worked there and were willing to share their expertise willingly. I loved my patients and the supervision I got from senior staff. The staff meetings were useful and educational. Problems actually got solved. I felt valued for 95% of the time.
cons: A major downside was that there was some acting out of professional jealousy by one or two staff members that made life difficult for other staff. At one point, a staff person was presented as a patient at a case conference, with his/her identity only thinly disguised. Management was not able to stop these events as they happened without warning and damage-control in such situations after the fact is frankly a bit like trying to restore New Orleans after the levees gave way.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Cambridge, MA
pros: Loyal colleagues, great pharmacist that had been hired 2015 and before. Low cost health plan not the greatest plan. Great medical record system.
cons: Parking is not free nor on site. Work ethic skills are not taken into consideration for growth within the pharmacy department (not inpatient) if you aren’t the manager/directors favorite. Work environment are always hostile. They do not care about culture NOR values! They will bully and discriminate you.

job_title: RN-IV Therapy-Cambridge Hospital in Quincy, MA
pros:
I really feel like there is a great sense of comradery here at Cambridge Hospital. Every nurse or other employee I encounter during my day is extremely friendly, outgoing, and you can definitely tell they are dedicated to their careers as well as providing the best possible care for their patients.  Even though I am just perdiem, I thoroughly enjoy and look forward to my days working at Cambridge Hospital and I have had nothing but positive experiences working here so far. Management and HR are very organized, supportive and easy to communicate with if you have questions or concerns. 
I do work full-time at in town hospital and when I step foot into Cambridge Hospital for my shift it is like a breath of fresh air, you can't beat that personable and close community hospital feel!
cons: None, I have nothing negative to say

pros: locations are convenient to get to
cons:
Management doesn’t care about employees, severely understaffed at all times, 70% of the patient population doesn’t speak English so you’re constantly using third party translation services just to do the simplest transactions. Always busy, you leave feeling over worked and underpaid every day. Worst locations are the main hospital in Cambridge and Malden...both are basically drowning in work daily.  
Training is basically non existent and you constantly feel like you don’t know anything because they’re too busy too actually show you how to do your job which in turn frustrates you and your coworkers. No room for growth your pay is minuscule compared to what you put up with on a day to day basis.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Cambridge, MA
pros: Great Pay/Great Benefits, Friendly Staff for most-part / CHA is committed to serving the underprivileged/low income community while still giving the amazing care Boston is known for.  I loved working for them and are non-profit - they help so many people and I respect that a lot.
cons:
#1 Reason left:  The psych unit is only floor that doesn't offer 12-hour shifts!  It's pretty unfair, as almost all the unit wanted 12-hrs like the rest of the hospital.  I wish upper management had helped us out.

#2:  Management will turn on you quickly if you are opinionated or don't give what they want.

pros: Not many Pros at all.  Pay is average and you don't get a raise after a year of working there, which is also not very significant.
cons: Extremely understaffed,  never really had a proper training from the beginning.  Not big on growth  unless you're favored by manager or unless you're kissing managements Behind. It doesn't matter how hard you work you would get 0 recognition.

job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Malden, MA
pros: Excellent benefits, union positions, excellent pay in the market overall, a teaching hospital that works to focus on education which facilitates the continued education of excusing staff also. Diverse population with many challenges; not easy to work with but very rewarding. Most staff are clearly there because they love the population.
cons: Management heavy with lots of disconnection between staff and managers. High management turnover. Sometimes vision of work is unclear due to managers who don't agree with each other. Different departments feel very fragmented and don't collaborate easily.

pros: The organization is deeply committed to improving the health of the community it serves. It provides not just quality health care but also various kinds of community social support and engagement. The smaller clinics are embedded within the communities that serve a highly diverse population in terms of cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
cons: Because it is so spread out, the management structure is not as robust. The benefit package is ok. The health insurance only covers care within CHA, which enters some ethical grey area, since people might have to seek care from their coworkers.

pros: Good place to work.  Culturally diverse population served.  Good support from interpreters so it is easy to get your work done quickly and safely.  I enjoyed working there.
cons: Parking, you live and die by the shuttle schedule.  Can add about 20 mins to your commute.  If you have a late shift you have to hope that there will be room in the lot for your car,

cons: Toxic culture. Management is awful. The only good managers leave the organization pretty quickly. It’s a miserable place to have to go to everyday. They will eat your soul.

cons: Not enough resources to maintain the facilities. Need to make decisions based on best business practices and not politics. The 14 unions make it difficult to run efficiently.
